references.B04SCH01USGP: Schmidly, D. J. 2004. The mammals of Texas. Revised ed. University of Texas Press, Austin.
references.B90ZEI02USGP: Zeiner, D. C., et al., editors. 1990. California's wildlife. Vol. II. Mammals. California Dept. Fish & Game, Sacramento. xi + 407 pp.

habitat_description:
Great Plains/Southwest:
This species, native to India, Nepal, and Sri Lanka, was introduced to the Edwards Plateau region of Texas around 1932 on private hunting ranches. It subsequently escaped fenced areas and began naturalizing to the area and expanding its range, becoming the most abundant exotic ungulate in the state (Schmidly 2004). Schmidly (2004) describes habitat: "Axis deer are inhabitants of secondary forest lands broken here and there by glades, with an understory of grasses, forbs, and tender shoots which supply adequate drinking water and shade. They tend to avoid rugged terrain. Their food consists largely of grasses at all seasons, augmented with browse. Green grasses less than 10 cm high seem to be preferred. In Texas, they graze on grasses such as paspalum, switchgrass, and little bluestem. Sedges are favorite spring foods. Browse species include live oak, hackberry, and sumac."

Northwest:
Animals from the San Franciso Zoo were introduced to the Marin County, California Point Reyes area in 1947 and 1948 where several hundred now graze livestock pastures, coastal scrub, and closed-cone pine and cypress forests. "Habitat pattern consists of coastal grassland, interspersed with northern coastal scrub and Bishop pine forests. Conversion of scrub and forest into pasture, and moderate grazing by livestock, appear to increase preferred forage." ([Elliott et al. 2005] based on Zeiner et al. 1990).
